Situation1: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story: The radio crackled with urgent voices as I scanned the radar, my heart pounding. A sudden route closure had forced dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport, and every second counted. As an air traffic controller, I was expected to manage the chaos, keep the skies safe, and prevent disaster. My headset pressed against my ear, drowning out the world, but not the memory that today was the main weekly service at the church. As the community’s priest, I was expected to lead the prayers, offer comfort, and be present for everyone who looked to me for spiritual guidance. The clock ticked closer to the service time. My phone buzzed with messages from parishioners, asking if I would be there. My hands trembled as I issued instructions to pilots, my mind torn between the lives in the sky and the souls in the pews. The weight of both uniforms pressed on me, and I felt myself pulled in two directions, each demanding all of me, each unwilling to wait.
